head.title: Effect of TiO2 on the Performance of Mn/Na2WO4 Catalysts in Oxidative Coupling of Methane | Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research

meta.content: Effect of TiO2 on the Performance of Mn/Na2WO4 Catalysts in Oxidative Coupling of Methane

The oxidation coupling of methane (OCM) has received attention as a direct route to produce C2 chemicals. Although the OCM is energetically more efficient than the conventional process, however, it provides relatively low C2 yield and CH4 conversion at lower temperatures. In this study, TiO2 and Ce were used as a support and a promoter to facilitate CH4 conversion by providing more available oxygen species in the Mn/Na2WO4-based catalysts. Additionally, the performance of TiO2-supported catalysts was compared with that of the conventional Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst. Various techniques including X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and H2 temperature-programmed reduction were conducted to evaluate the effect of TiO2 and Ce. The 1.9 % Mn-5% Na2WO4–5% Ce/TiO2 showed the best performance, with a maximum C2 yield of 26.1% at 775 °C and the CH4/O2 ratio of 2. This yield was higher than that of the Mn/Na2WO4-based catalysts examined in this study, indicating that TiO2 is a promising support for OCM catalysts.

div.p:
The oxidation coupling of methane (OCM) has received attention as a direct route to produce C
2
chemicals. Although the OCM is energetically more efficient than the conventional process, however, it provides relatively low C
2
yield and CH
4
conversion at lower temperatures. In this study, TiO
2
and Ce were used as a support and a promoter to facilitate CH
4
conversion by providing more available oxygen species in the Mn/Na
2
WO
4
-based catalysts. Additionally, the performance of TiO
2
-supported catalysts was compared with that of the conventional Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/SiO
2
catalyst. Various techniques including X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and H
2
temperature-programmed reduction were conducted to evaluate the effect of TiO
2
and Ce. The 1.9 % Mn-5% Na
2
WO
4
–5% Ce/TiO
2
showed the best performance, with a maximum C
2
yield of 26.1% at 775 °C and the CH
4
/O
2
ratio of 2. This yield was higher than that of the Mn/Na
2
WO
4
-based catalysts examined in this study, indicating that TiO
2
is a promising support for OCM catalysts.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The abundance of natural gas and the global depletion of crude oil have led to increased interest in developing the process for methane conversion into high-value products.
(1,2)
Despite a lot of attention, however, methane has been underutilized as a chemical feedstock due to the lack of efficient methods of direct conversion to high-value chemicals.
(3)
Generally, natural gas is primarily used for power generation, residential uses, and industrial applications including syngas production through endothermic steam reforming. Current commercial catalytic processes to convert methane to platform chemicals such as olefins and alcohols are based on an indirect route that involves a two-step process in which methane is first converted to syngas, followed by the Fischer–Tropsch process. However, this indirect route is economical only for a large-scale process because it suffers from low energy efficiency and high capital and operating costs.

As an alternative to the indirect process, the direct conversion is being considered via the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM). The OCM is a heterogeneous (solid–gas) catalytic process through which methane can be transformed directly into ethane and ethylene, crucial building blocks for an extensive range of chemicals.
(4)
This direct route is more energy-efficient than the indirect route since it bypasses the energy-intensive endothermic reforming step of syngas formation. However, the OCM poses challenges resulting from the high driving force to full oxidation to CO or CO
2
.

In the OCM process, methane is activated on the catalyst surface to form gaseous methyl radicals, which then is desorbed, followed by a homogeneous coupling step of the methyl radicals to yield ethane.
(5−8)
Ethane can then be converted to ethylene through further oxidative dehydrogenation.
(9,10)
As mentioned above, however, the OCM reaction faces a low C
2
yield because of undesired products such as CO and CO
2
, which are more thermodynamically favored than the C
2
products.
(11,12)

Since a pioneering work by Keller and Bhasin,
(4)
extensive studies have been conducted to develop OCM catalysts, which satisfy the commercially available target of a minimum C
2
yield of ∼30% at a C
2
selectivity of ∼90%.
(13−15)
Among reported catalysts for OCM, one of the most promising catalysts is Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/SiO
2
, which shows significant performance at 800–900 °C.
(16)
The role of each component in Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/SiO
2
was investigated by many researchers. Tungstate is known to be involved in the stabilization of catalysts and participated as an active site,
(17,18)
while sodium contributed to increases in C
2
selectivity by increasing catalyst basicity.
(19,20)

Recently, it has been reported that doping Ti into the Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/SiO
2
catalyst has a positive effect on the OCM reaction efficiency. Wang et al.
(21,22)
showed that the TiO
2
-doped Mn
2
O
3
–NaWO
4
/SiO
2
catalyst, which was prepared by the solution combustion synthesis method, has high activity for OCM at relatively low temperatures and that the formation of MnTiO
3
triggers the MnTiO
3
↔ Mn
2
O
3
cycle for O
2
activation. Yunarti et al.
(23)
also reported that Mg/Ti-doped SiO
2
-supported Na
2
WO
4
/Mn catalysts improved C
2
yield (23.1% C
2
yield at 800 °C), compared to the Na
2
WO
4
/Mn/SiO
2
catalyst. These reports show that Ti plays a significant role in improving the OCM reaction.

Today, TiO
2
is widely used as a support of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) due to its low cost, high surface area, reducibility properties, abundance, and nontoxicity.
(24)
Most recently, the possibility of TiO
2
as a support of OCM catalysts has been investigated using mesoporous TiO
2
,
(25)
WO
3
/TiO
2
,
(26)
and Ce–Na
2
WO
4
/TiO
2
.
(27)
For the Li–Mn/WO
3
/TiO
2
catalyst, it was reported that the highest C
2
yield of 16.3% was achieved at 750 °C. According to Cheng et al., this was due to stronger surface basicity and more abundant lattice oxygen in the catalyst.
(26)

In this study, commercial TiO
2
was used as a support of Mn/Na
2
WO
4
to confirm the effect of catalytic performance on the OCM reaction. It was compared to the performance of the conventional Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/SiO
2
catalyst. Additionally, the effect of Ce as a promoter to enhance oxygen mobility was investigated. Various techniques including X-ray diffraction (XRD), H
2
temperature-programmed reduction (H
2
-TPR), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were employed to understand the effect of TiO
2
and Ce on the OCM performance.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/TiO
2
(MNWTi) and Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/SiO
2
(MNWSi) catalysts tested in this study were prepared by the wet-impregnation method using manganese (II) nitrate hydrate (Mn(NO
3
)
2
, 98% pure, Sigma-Aldrich), sodium tungstate dihydrate (Na
2
WO
4
·H
2
O, 99.7% pure, Chem-Impex), silica (SiO
2
, high purity grade, Sigma-Aldrich), and a commercial anatase titanium dioxide (TiO
2
, Cristal Global Co).

Briefly, the TiO
2
or SiO
2
support was impregnated with an aqueous solution containing Mn(NO
3
)
2
and Na
2
WO
4
·H
2
O as precursors yielding 1.9 wt % Mn and 5 wt % Na
2
WO
4
. The water in the mixed solution was removed using a rotary evaporator (Rotavapor R-210 Buchi Co.) and was further dried in an oven at 103 °C for 24 h. Finally, all the catalysts were pulverized and calcined in air at 800 °C. To synthesize Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/Ce/TiO
2
(MNW[
x
]CeTi;
x
= 5 or 10), cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO
3
)
3
·6H
2
O, 99.5% pure, Alfa Aesar) as a precursor for Ce was added to the solution containing Mn(NO
3
)
2
and Na
2
WO
4
·H
2
O and followed the same procedure as described above.

XPS was performed using Alpha-K (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with an Al Ka monochromatic (1486.6 eV) as an excitation source. The powdered catalysts were analyzed without sputtering or etching to maintain the vacuum of the XPS apparatus at 10
–6
Pa. The elements present in the catalyst sample were identified by the wide-scan XPS spectra. Using the software provided by the manufacturer (Thermo Advantage), the spectra were further analyzed to adjust all binding energies based on the C–C bond (284.6 eV) in the C 1s peaks.

In addition, the structure of the catalysts was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.1506 nm) within the 2θ range between 10 and 90
o
at a scanning velocity of 4
o
min
–1
.

The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was also conducted in a chemisorption analyzer (Autochem 2920, Micrometrics) to evaluate the redox properties of the catalysts. The catalyst samples were first pretreated under 5% O
2
/N
2
at 100 °C for 30 min and then reduced at 30 °C under 10% H
2
/N
2
for 30 min for the purpose of stabilization. Then, the consumption of H
2
was monitored while the catalyst layer was heated at a rate of 10 °C/min to 900 °C.

The experiments were carried out in a fixed-bed reactor where 0.5 g of catalyst (40–50 mesh) was loaded in a quartz tube with an inner diameter of 8 mm. A quartz wool layer was located to hold the catalyst bed in place. Gas feed mixtures were prepared using mass flow controllers while maintaining the total flow rate constant at 40 mL/min (feed ratio CH
4
/O
2
/N
2
= 2:1:1), where nitrogen was used as a carrier gas. The gases exiting the reactor passed through a cold trap (WCT-40, Daihan Scientific) to remove water, and their volumetric flow rates were then measured using a volumetric flow meter (ADM flow meter, Agilent). The outlet gases were analyzed by gas chromatography (6890, Agilent) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), equipped with a ShinCarbon ST 50/80 packed column (Agilent). The temperatures of the front sides of the catalyst bed were monitored during the reaction experiments. Various parameters including CH
4
conversion, C
2
selectivity, C
2
yield, and ethylene/ethane ratio are defined as follows
(1)
(2)
(3)
(4)

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
shows C
2
yield, CH
4
conversion, and C
2
selectivity as a function of temperature for MNWTi and MNWSi catalysts under the standard operating conditions (total flow rate 40 mL/min and feed ratio CH
4
/O
2
/N
2
= 2:1:1). With increasing temperature, CH
4
conversion for both catalysts increased from 26.8 to 50.8% for MNWTi and from 12.1 to 41.5% for MNWSi. On the other hand, C
2
selectivity increased with temperature up to 775 °C, 56.5, and 42.7% for MNWTi and MNWSi and then decreased as the formation of CO and CO
2
increases by deep oxidation. These trends are good in agreement with other prior studies for OCM.
(28,29)
Unlike CH
4
conversion and C
2
selectivity, different trends were observed in C
2
yield within the range of temperature examined in this study (725–800 °C). The C
2
yield with MNWTi was more influenced by C
2
selectivity, while CH
4
conversion had a greater effect on the MNWSi catalyst. As shown in
Figure
1
b, 775 °C was found to be the optimum temperature for MNWTi, with a maximum C
2
yield of 25.9%. For MNWSi, however, C
2
yield increased with increasing temperature and C
2
yield of 15.6% was achieved at 800 °C. The ethylene/ethane ratio tended to increase as the temperature increased. At 775 °C, the ethylene/ethane ratios are 4.1 and 3.1 with MNWTi and MNWSi, respectively. These results suggest that TiO
2
is promising as a support of Mn/Na
2
WO
4
-based catalysts for OCM.

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) CH
4
conversion and C
2
selectivity and (b) C
2
yield as a function of temperature for MNWSi and MNWTi catalysts (total flow rate: 40 sccm, CH
4
/O
2
/N
2
= 2:1:1).

div.div:
Based on these results, the MNWTi catalyst was further investigated with varying CH
4
/O
2
ratio in the feed in a temperature range of 725–800 °C. While varying the CH
4
/O
2
ratio from 2 to 5, the total flow rate and the CH
4
flow rate in the feed were kept constant at 40 and 20 mL/min, respectively. Similar to the results observed in
Figure
1
, the CH
4
conversion increased, while the C
2
selectivity increased and then decreased with reactor temperature. It may be also seen that the CH
4
conversion decreased with the CH
4
/O
2
ratio because of the limited amount of oxygen in the reactor and the complete conversion of O
2
. For example, the CH
4
conversion decreased from 50.8 to 29.8% with an increase in CH
4
/O
2
from 2 to 5 at 800 °C. On the contrary, an increase in the CH
4
/O
2
ratio increased the C
2
selectivity because of carbon oxides (CO and CO
2
) as the reaction between CH
4
and O
2
decreases. The C
2
selectivity increased from 49.0 to 71.7% with increasing CH
4
/O
2
at 800 °C and the maximum C
2
selectivity of 89.31% was obtained with CH
4
/O
2
= 5 at 750 °C. Due to the trade-off between CH
4
conversion and C
2
selectivity described above, the maximum C
2
yield is typically observed in the OCM.
Figure
2
c clearly shows that with increasing temperature, the C
2
yield increased for a higher CH
4
/O
2
ratio (= 4 and 5), while it reached a maximum and then decreased for a lower CH
4
/O
2
ratio (= 2 and 3). The maximum C
2
yields of 25.9 and 23.7% were measured at 775 °C for CH
4
/O
2
= 2 and 3, respectively.

div.p:
Figure 2. Effect of the CH
4
/O
2
feed ratio on the (a) C
2
yield, (b) CH
4
conversion, and (c) C
2
selectivity for the MNWTi catalyst (CH
4
flow rate: 20 sccm, total flow rate: 40 sccm).

div.div:
Although various reaction schemes for OCM have been proposed, there exists no consensus. According to a general reaction network accepted, CH
4
is first activated to form methyl radicals (CH
3
*), which occurs via a reaction between CH
4
and oxygen species available on the catalyst.
(7,30)
In this context, it can be expected that the availability of oxygen species on the catalyst surface may play a critical role in enhancing the first step of OCM, activation of CH
4
. For this reason, Ce was added into the MNWTi catalyst (MNWCeTi) in this study, and the performance was examined. Ceria is well-known as a substance with abundant oxygen vacancy and has often been employed as a promoter in OCM catalysts.
(31)

Figure
3
shows the effect of Ce content (0, 2, 5, and 10 wt %) in the MNWCeTi catalyst on CH
4
conversion, C
2
selectivity, and C
2
yield at 775 and 800 °C where higher C
2
yields were observed for the MNWTi catalyst. It was found that with an increase in Ce loading, the CH
4
conversion increased, while the C
2
selectivity decreased. Indeed, a maximum CH
4
conversion of 57.4% was observed with MNW10CeTi (10 wt % Ce) at 800 °C. With increasing Ce loading from 5 to 10 wt %, however, a significant decrease in C
2
selectivity from 52.8 and 45.9 to 35.1 and 29.7% was observed at 775 and 800 °C, respectively. As expected, as the Ce loading increased, the availability of oxygen on the catalyst surface increased, resulting in similar results as the effect of the CH
4
/O
2
ratio. As a consequence, 5 wt % of Ce loading was found to be the optimum in this study and provided a maximum C
2
yield of 26.1% at 775 °C. From the results, it was concluded that Ce improves methane activation by offering additionally available oxygen species on the catalyst.

div.p:
Figure 3. Effect of the Ce loading on the (a) C
2
yield, (b) CH
4
conversion, and (c) C
2
selectivity for MNW[
x
]CeTi catalysts (total flow rate: 40 sccm, CH
4
/O
2
/N
2
= 2:1:1).

div.div:
The BET surface area was measured for the fresh catalysts. The surface area was determined to be relatively small (<3 m
2
/g), and similar values of the surface area were observed for all the catalysts examined in this study. The small surface area is likely due to the high calcination temperature (800 °C).

Figure
4
shows the XRD patterns of MNWSi, MNWTi, and MNWCeTi catalysts. The XRD pattern of MNWSi shows peaks assigned to α-cristobalite (2θ = 22.1, 28.6, 31.5, 36.1, 42.9, and 44.9) and Na
2
WO
4
(2θ = 16.9, 27.8, 32.4, 48.8, 52.1, and 57.1).
(32)
It is known that the cristobalite structure stabilizes Na
2
WO
4
and promotes C
2
selective for OCM reactions.
(23,33,34)
Both MNWTi and MNWCeTi catalysts exhibit peaks of anatase (2θ = 25.3 and 39.2) and rutile (2θ = 27.4, 36.1, 41.3, 44.1, 54.4, and 56.6) of TiO
2
.
(26)
Although commercial TiO
2
of the anatase phase was used in preparing catalysts investigated in the present study, some anatase structure was converted into rutile structure when calcined at high temperature. With the addition of Ce in the MNWCeTi catalyst, the peaks corresponding to CeO
2
and Ce
x
Ti
(1–
x
)
are shown at 28.6 and 30.6. It is noteworthy that the peaks of Na and W were not observed from TiO
2
-supported catalysts (MNWTi and MNWCeTi). It is likely because Na
2
WO
4
is highly dispersed over the TiO
2
in these types of catalysts, which will be further discussed later.

div.p: Figure 4. XRD patterns of MNWSi, MNWTi, and MNW5CeTi catalysts.

div.div:
Wang, et al.
(21,22)
recently reported that the chemical cycle between MnTiO
3
and Mn
2
O
3
results in O
2
activation to improve both activity and selectivity in OCM at low temperatures. From the XRD patterns in our study, the peak of MnTiO
3
(2θ = 32.5) is observed in both MNWTi and MNWCeTi catalysts. In addition, the peak at 2θ = 33.2 in MNWCeTi is attributed to Mn
2
O
3
. This is in good agreement with that reported in the literature, the presence of MnTiO
3
and Mn
2
O
3
in the catalysts triggers O
2
activation at low temperatures. As a result, better performance was achieved with TiO
2
-supported catalysts, compared to the conventional MNWSi catalyst for OCM.

XPS was used to investigate the valence state of Mn in catalysts examined in this study (MNWSi, MNWTi, and MNW5CeTi). It was reported that the activity of OCM catalysts are influenced by a chemical cycle between MnTiO
3
and Mn
2
O
3
, indicating that Mn
2+
and Mn
3+
play a key role in improving the activity of the OCM catalyst. Using XPS analysis, however, the assignments of the valence state of Mn
2+
(MnWO
4
or MnTiO
3
) and Mn
3+
(Mn
2
O
3
) are difficult because the binding energies corresponding to Mn
2+
and Mn
3+
in the Mn 2p spectrum are very close to each other. In the present work, therefore, the XPS spectrum for Mn 2p signals was deconvoluted to elucidate the valence states of the Mn species in the OCM catalysts using a software.

The XPS spectra for Mn 2p photoelectrons are shown in
Figure
5
. The broad peak of the Mn 2p photoelectrons from 636 to 658 eV is deconvoluted into three components corresponding to (Mn
2+
+ Mn
3+
), Mn
4+
, and Mn-satellite with binding energies 641.2, 642.2, and 644.5 eV, respectively.
(35)
From the integrated area of each component, the ratio of Mn
2+
and Mn
3+
(Mn
2+
+ Mn
3+
) to total Mn species (Mn
2+
+ Mn
3+
+ Mn
4+
) in the OCM catalysts (MNWSi, MNWTi, and MNW5CeTi) was evaluated. It can be seen from
Figure
5
that the ratio of (Mn
2+
and Mn
3+
)/Mn
total
for MNWTi (63.27%) is higher than that of MNWSi (53.29%), indicating that TiO
2
as a support leads to an increase in activity by enriching Mn
2+
and Mn
3+
in the catalyst. With the addition of Ce to MNWTi, this ratio is further increased to 70.28% (MNW5CeTi). It was noted in the XRD analysis that the peak corresponding to MnWO
4
was not observed in TiO
2
-supported catalysts. Considering the XRD results, the formation of MnWO
4
seems to be relatively small because Mn species exist in the form of MnTiO
3
and Mn
2
O
3
structures in the TiO
2
-supported catalysts.

div.p:
Figure 5. XP spectra of MNWSi, MNWTi, and MNW5CeTi catalysts: red and orange numbers with arrow indicate the ratio of surface (Mn
2+
+ Mn
3+
) and Mn
4+
species, respectively.

div.div:
To further understand the effect of the valence state of Mn on the activity of the catalyst, the correlation between the ratio of (Mn
2+
+ Mn
3+
)/Mn
total
and CH
4
conversion was investigated for different reactor temperatures.
Figure
6
clearly demonstrates that the Mn valence state is strongly related to CH
4
conversion in the OCM. Indeed, the CH
4
conversion is almost linearly proportional to the ratio (Mn
2+
+ Mn
3+
)/Mn
total
in the temperature range studied. It is believed that MnTiO
3
and Mn
2
O
3
corresponding to Mn
2+
and Mn
3+
are key components facilitating methyl radicals by providing more available oxygen species.

div.p:
Figure 6. Correlation between the (Mn
2+
+ Mn
3+
)/Mn
total
ratio and the CH
4
conversion.

div.div:
Finally, H
2
-TPR analysis was performed to measure the redox characteristics of catalysts, as shown in
Figure
7
. According to the H
2
-TPR analysis, two reduction peaks at 650–750 °C and above 850 °C were observed for all the catalyst samples. The peak at 650–750 °C could be owing to the reduction of Mn
2
O
3
, MnTiO
3
, and TiO
2
,
(21,26)
while another peak at above 850 °C is assigned to Na
2
WO
4
.
(26,36)
It was also found that the peak area by the reduction increased as Ce was added, indicating that redox property was improved by the addition of Ce. Although Na
2
WO
4
was not detected in TiO
2
-supported catalysts by the XRD analysis, it was observed by the H
2
-TPR analysis, which can be likely that Na
2
WO
4
is highly dispersed on the MNWTi and MNWCeTi catalysts.
Figure
7
shows that more oxygen species are available in TiO
2
-supported catalysts in the OCM reaction temperature range (700–800 °C), comparing to MNWSi, which is in good agreement with the results from the XPS analysis.

div.p:
Figure 7. H
2
-TPR profile of MNWSi, MNWTi, and MNW5CeTi catalysts.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
It has been reported that Mn/Na
2
WO
4
/SiO
2
(MNWSi) is most promising for the OCM reaction among numerous catalysts studied. In the present work, the conventional OCM catalyst (MNWSi) was modified using TiO
2
and Ce as a support and a promoter, respectively. With varying reactor temperature and CH
4
/O
2
ratio, the performance of the TiO
2
-supported catalysts (MNWTi and MNWCeTi) was investigated and compared with that of the MNWSi. With increasing temperature, CH
4
conversion increased, while C
2
selectivity increased and then decreased as the formation of carbon oxides (CO and CO
2
) increases. The CH
4
conversion decreased with the CH
4
/O
2
ratio because of the limited amount of oxygen while an increase in the CH
4
/O
2
ratio increased the C
2
selectivity because carbon oxides decrease. It was found that the CH
4
conversion and C
2
yield were significantly improved with TiO
2
-supported catalysts. As compared to the MNWSi catalyst, the CH
4
conversion and C
2
yield with MNWTi increased from 28.5 to 46.0% and from 12.1 to 25.9% at 775 °C and CH
4
/O
2
ratio of 2, respectively. With the addition of 5 wt % Ce, the C
2
yield was slightly increased to 26.1%. In the TiO
2
-supported catalysts, the presence of MnTiO
3
and Mn
2
O
3
, which are reported to trigger O
2
activation at low temperature, was confirmed by XRD analysis. In addition, the deconvoluted XPS spectra for Mn 2p photoelectrons show that the ratio of (Mn
2+
and Mn
3+
), key components facilitating methyl radicals, to total Mn species was high for TiO
2
-supported catalysts. Finally, the H
2
-TPR analysis reveals that the formation of MnTiO
3
and the addition of Ce as a promoter provide more oxygen species available in the OCM reaction temperature range. The results suggest that TiO
2
-supported catalysts are promising for the OCM reaction by promoting the activation to methyl radicals at relatively low temperatures.

The literature for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) on supported Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts is systematically and critically reviewed. The influence of the precursors, starting SiO2 support crystallinity, synthesis method, calcination temp., and OCM reaction conditions on the catalyst structure is examd. The supported Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst system is found to be dynamic with the catalyst structure quite dependent on the set of variables. Although almost all of the reported studies have detd. the catalyst cryst. structures under ambient conditions (room temp. and air exposed), recent in situ/operando characterization study under OCM reaction conditions revealed that all previously detected cryst. phases of the active Mn-Na-W-O components are not present because the reaction temp. is above the m.ps. of their oxides. The presence of Na also induces the crystn. of the silica support to SiO2 (cristobalite) at elevated temps. The nature of the surface active sites under OCM reaction conditions is still not known because of the absence of in situ/operando surface spectroscopy characterization studies under relevant reaction conditions. Consequently, the proposed structure-activity models in the literature are highly speculative since they are lacking supporting data. The rate-detg.-step involves activation of the methane C-H bond by at. surface O* as demonstrated by a kinetic isotope effect (KIE) between CH4 and CD4. Although the reaction kinetics follow a Langmuir-Hinshelwood type mechanism, r = [CH4]1[O2]1/2, isotopic 18O2-16O2 studies have shown that the catalyst lattice also provides O* for the OCM reaction suggesting involvement of a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. Recommendations are given regarding the exptl. investigations that could establish the fundamental reaction aspects of OCM by supported Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts that would allow for the rational design of improved catalysts.

ethylene [74-85-1] And ethane [74-84-0] were synthesized by catalytic oxidative coupling of CH4 [74-82-8] at 1 atm and 500-1000°. A great no. of metal oxides, supported on an α-alumina support, were screened for activity and selectivity in the normal, concurrent feeding mode of reactants, as well as, in the sequential or feed programming mode. The concurrent feeding expts. gave low selectivities of 0-20 %, while feed programming expts. gave selectivities of ∼50%. In the latter case, however, a stainless-steel reactor became catalytically active for burning of methane to carbon oxides. Although a stainless-steel reactor was used in most of the work reported here, a quartz reactor was inert. The most active catalysts for C2 formation were the oxides of Sn, Pb, Sb, Bi, Tl, Cd, and Mn, while Li, Mg, Zn, Ti, Zr, Mo, Fe, Cr, W, Cu, Ag, Pt, Ce, V, B, and Al showed little or no activity. The low C2-forming activity of Pt and Ce, however, may be due to the secondary burning of C2's on the stainless-steel reactor walls. This also makes it difficult to quantify the C2-forming selectivity of the active metal oxides. The active metals seem to exhibit a common characteristic: they can cycle between at least two oxidn. states. Although there are differences in selectivities in C2 formation and carbon oxides formation, no correlation seems to exist with the free-energy changes in the oxidn. states. A possible mechanism for C2 formation from methane is proposed.

A review with 45 refs. The very large reserves of methane, which often are found in remote regions, could serve as a feedstock for the prodn. of chems. and as a source of energy well into the 21st century. Although methane currently is being used in such important applications as the heating of homes and the generation of hydrogen for ammonia synthesis, its potential for the prodn. of ethylene or liq. hydrocarbon fuels has not been fully realized. A no. of strategies are being explored at levels that range from fundamental science to engineering technol. These include: (a) stream and carbon dioxide reforming or partial oxidn. of methane to form carbon monoxide and hydrogen, followed by Fischer-Tropsch chem., (b) the direct oxidn. of methane to methanol and formaldehyde, (c) oxidative coupling of methane to ethylene, and (d) direct conversion to aroms. and hydrogen in the absence of oxygen. Each alternative has its own set of limitations; however, economical sepn. is common to all with the most important issues being the sepn. of oxygen from air and the sepn. of hydrogen or hydrocarbons from dil. product streams. Extensive utilization of methane for the prodn. of fuels and chems. appears to be near, but current economic uncertainties limit the amt. of research activity and the implementation of emerging technologies.

The mechanism of the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), a reaction discovered in the early 1980s, and the development of approaches to kinetic description of this reaction are analyzed. In addn. to being of potential practical significance as a single-step synthetic route from methane to ethylene, a valuable chem. and petrochem. semiproduct, OCM was the first heterogeneous-homogeneous process of this hitherto unknown type. Its distinctive feature is that it is impossible to sep. det. the methane conversion via the main pathway (into C2 hydrocarbons) in the homogeneous phase and on the catalyst surface, because reactive intermediates (Me radicals) result from the interaction of methane mols. with active sites of the surface, while the primary OCM product (ethane) results from the recombination of these radicals in the gas phase. The correlation between the phenomenol. regularities of the OCM process and its mechanism, the correlation between the nature of the active sites and the mechanism of activation of methane and oxygen, and the possibility of constructing a self-consistent kinetic model taking into account the specific features of the process-redox nature of the active sites and the free-radical character of the major intermediate compds.-are analyzed in detail.

A gas-phase reaction network involving reactive intermediates such as alkyl and alkyl peroxide radicals and alkyl hydroperoxides have long remained a mystery in oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) and oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODHE) reactions. Herein we report direct observations of gas-phase reactive intermediates including CH2, CH3•, C2H5•, CH3OO•, C2H5OO•, CH3OOH, and C2H5OOH during OCM and ODHE reactions over Li/MgO catalysts with an online synchrotron VUV photoionization mass spectrometer connected to a catalytic reactor with adjustable distances between the catalyst bed and the sampling nozzle of the mass spectrometer. Secondary reactions of these reactive intermediates in the gas phase are elucidated, and the reaction network of OCM and ODHE reactions is established. These results greatly deepen the mechanistic understanding of OCM and ODHE reactions necessary for developing efficient catalysts and designing proper reactors.

Four seemingly simple transformations related to the chemistry of methane will be addressed from mechanistic and conceptual points of view: 1) metal-mediated dehydrogenation to form metal carbene complexes, 2) the hydrogen-atom abstraction step in the oxidative dimerization of methane, 3) the mechanisms of the CH(4)→CH(3)OH conversion, and 4) the initial bond scission (C-H vs. O-H) as well as the rate-limiting step in the selective CH(3)OH→CH(2)O oxidation. State-of-the-art gas-phase experiments, in conjunction with electronic-structure calculations, permit identification of the elementary reactions at a molecular level and thus allow us to unravel detailed mechanistic aspects. Where appropriate, these results are compared with findings from related studies in solution or on surfaces.

A reaction-transport model that combines gas-phase reactions occurring within interstitial and intrapellet voids with surface reactions occurring on catalytic sites was used to describe the oxidative coupling of methane in packed-bed reactors, a typical example of bimodal (homogeneous-heterogeneous) reaction systems. A kinetic model for gas-phase reactions was assembled from available literature data; it describes well exptl. results in empty reactors. Simulations suggest that C2 yields greater than 8-9% are unattainable with CH4/O2 mixts. in homogeneous reactors. Staging the introduction of the oxygen reactant along the reactor length minimizes secondary oxidn. reactions by lowering the local O2 pressures, and leads to a slight increase in max. yield (12% for 200 injection points) but also to much larger required reactor vols. The introduction of an ideal catalytic function (Me and Et radical formation without full oxidn.) also increases max. C2 yields by increasing the concn. of Me radicals involved in bimol. coupling steps. However, C2 yields greater than 30% require selective catalysts with very high turnover rates (>100 s-1); higher rates become ultimately limited by intrapellet diffusion rates. Again, staging oxygen by multiple injection schemes increases attainable yields but requires larger reactor vols. and catalytic sites with low reaction order («1) in oxygen. For optimum conditions, staged oxygen injection techniques lead to C2 yields as high as 50%.

The chem. looping concept (CLC) has been implemented to suppress the formation of COx in an oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) reactor under a wide range of conditions. In comparison to the normal co-feeding strategy, this technique resulted in an enhanced C2 selectivity at the same methane conversions. Nevertheless, the obtained yield never exceeded 25% which is still lower than the min. value needed for industrializing OCM. The CLC was applied in mechanistic studies to investigate the consecutive reaction of the main products of OCM, i.e. ethane and ethene. The performance of the reaction of C2 components at 750 °C in the chem. looping reactor was compared with that obtained in the co-feeding expts. The effect of the surface adsorbed oxygen species on the reaction of both ethane and ethene was investigated. The results of these expts. reveal that some of the mechanistic assumptions about the OCM reaction are not compatible with the nature of MnxOy-Na2WO4/SiO2, one of the most stable and best performing catalysts known for this reaction. The yield limitation is shown to be inherent to the catalyst. However, this limitation should be solvable through the modified process concept aiming at the prodn. of ethane in a sepd. first step.

A review. Over the past few decades, natural gas prodn. has increased due to shale gas and tight oil prodn. This increase in availability and prodn. has prompted research into unconventional ways to use methane, the main component in natural gas. Methane can be directly converted to more valuable C2 products using oxidative coupling (OCM). This process has been studied extensively over the last several decades, however, it has not been commercialized due to low yields of the C2 products. In this viewpoint article, we discuss the thermodn. and kinetic obstacles that lead to low C2 yields in this process, describe potential approaches to address the kinetic obstacles, express our opinion about important future research direction, and describe potential catalyst and reactor design challenges that will impact these future research directions.

MnO-Na2WO4/SiO2 is an active catalyst for the oxidative coupling of methane, with a remarkable stability and a suitable performance for an industrial application. MnO-Na2WO4 was supported on different support materials and the catalytic activity was studied with a parallel reactor system, allowing a direct comparison of all results. Considering the C2 yield and the potential practical application, SiO2 is indeed the best support material for this catalyst. However, the comparison in an X-S plot with a ref. MnO-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst indicates that SiC, Fe2O3-based oxides and TiO2-rutile are also promising support materials.

A review; Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 is one of the very few catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane, whose stability over extended times on stream has been reported by different research groups. The high stability turned Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 into an object of research, despite the rather complex compn. and structure. The nature of the active site or the active phase is unclear, in spite of the research on this catalytic system. This manuscript tries to critically summarize the literature on this system and to discuss the available information about the relationship of structure and activity.

The oxidative coupling of CH4 over Mn/Na2WO4/SIO2, Mn/Na2WO4/MgO, and NaMnO4/MgO catalysts was studied using both a co-feed flow system and a pulse reactor. Using a CH4/O2 ratio of ca. 8/1, at 800° and 1 atm, the CH4 conversion of 20% was achieved with C2+ selectivity of ≥80%, with no diluent in the reagents. The similar catalytic behaviors of the 3 catalysts suggest that a common active site, consisting of an Na-O-Mn species, may be involved. Results from a pulse reaction sequence (an O2 pulse followed by a series of pure CH4 pulses) indicate that the active species are not stable under reaction conditions unless gas phase O2 is present, and that bulk lattice oxygen does not participate in the CH4 coupling reaction when carried out in the co-feed mode. There is a linear relationship between the specific activity for CH4 conversion and the concn. of surface Mn, which is believed to be responsible for the activation of O2. The resulting form of oxygen then abstrs. a hydrogen atom from CH4. Sodium is essential for preventing the complete oxidn. of CH4, perhaps by isolating the Mn ions. The tungstate ions appear to impart stability to the catalysts.

Increased yields of higher hydrocarbons from CH4 [74-82-8] over MgO-SiO2 are obtained upon the addn. of alkali metals and alk. earths to the catalyst. Running redox cycles of alternating CH4 and air, a 15% Mn-5% Na pyrophosphate-SiO2 catalyst repeatedly gives a 17% yield of C2H6 [74-84-0], C2H4 [74-85-1], and higher hydrocarbons (77% selectivity and 22% conversion) for 2 min at 850° and gas space velocity 860 h-1. Characterization of Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 and Mn-Na2WO4/MgO catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane
Elkins, Trenton W.; Hagelin-Weaver, Helena E.
Applied Catalysis, A: General
(

),

Elsevier B.V.
)
In this study, one of the most active catalysts in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2, was investigated in detail using x-ray diffraction (x-ray diffraction) and XPS to obtain more information about this complex catalyst. A poorly active Mn-Na2WO4/MgO and two ref. catalysts, Mn/SiO2 and Na2WO4/SiO2, were also included. X-ray diffraction reveals the presence of Na2WO4, Mn2O3 and the α-cristobalite phase of SiO2 on the active Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, which all have been identified as very important in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM). In addn. to facilitating the transformation from amorphous to cryst. α-cristobalite SiO2, the presence of Na2WO4 also yields a higher surface concn. of manganese. While this is necessary, it is not sufficient, for a highly active catalyst, as the poorly active Mn-Na2WO4/MgO also has a high manganese surface concn. However, in contrast to the very stable Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, the MgO support is not able to stabilize the specific Na2WO4 and Mn2O3 phases and a no. of NaxWOy compds. with varying Na:W ratios together with MnO2 and mixed manganese compds. are identified by x-ray diffraction. The broad Na 1s and W 4f XPS peaks support the presence of more than one NaxWOy compd. on the surface of the Mn-Na2WO4/MgO catalyst. The fact that Na2WO4 and Mn2O3 are not stable on the MgO-supported catalyst is likely one reason for its poor activity, as the active site is believed to involve a distorted WO4 tetrahedron stabilized by Na (and α-cristobalite SiO2), and accessible Mn3+ in close proximity to the Na2WO4 may be necessary to yield a highly active catalyst. The Na:W surface concn. ratio of the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst is significantly higher (5.8) than the stoichiometric Na:W ratio of Na2WO4 (2.0) revealing a surface enriched in sodium. This is due to some of the sodium interacting closely with the SiO2 as evidenced by shifts in the Na 1s and Si 2p peaks to lower binding energies than expected for SiO2 and Na2WO4. The Na may be important in the activation of oxygen species on the surface toward hydrogen abstraction. The importance of the specific Na2WO4 oxide is further supported by the H4Na2WO6 phase which is obsd. on the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst after reaction. This phase has not been identified previously on the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, but corroborates earlier conclusions that Na2WO4 is important and suggests that Na2WO4 is indeed involved in the hydrogen abstraction from methane, the important first step in the oxidative coupling of methane. The strong interactions obsd. between all the species (Mn, Na, W and Si) on this catalyst may also indicate that the interface between Na2WO4 and Mn2O3 is important in this reaction.

Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) is a promising method for the direct conversion of methane to ethene and ethane (C2 products). Among the catalysts reported previously, Mn2O3-Na2WO4/SiO2 showed the highest conversion and selectivity, but only at 800° to 900°C, which represents a substantial challenge for commercialization. We report a TiO2-doped Mn2O3-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst by using Ti-MWW zeolite as TiO2 dopant as well as SiO2 support, enabling OCM with 26% conversion and 76% C2-C3 selectivity at 720°C because of MnTiO3 formation. MnTiO3 triggers the low-temp. Mn2+↔Mn3+ cycle for O2 activation while working synergistically with Na2WO4 to selectively convert methane to C2-C3. We also prepd. a practical Mn2O3-TiO2-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst in a ball mill. This catalyst can be transformed in situ into MnTiO3-Na2WO4/SiO2, yielding 22% conversion and 62% selectivity at 650°C. Our results will stimulate attempts to understand more fully the chem. of MnTiO3-governed low-temp. activity, which might lead to com. exploitation of a low-temp. OCM process.

The Mn2O3-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst is the most promising one among the enormous catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) but only at above 800 °C. No doubt that lowering temp. of the OCM process is at the forefront of this catalysis field. A promising low-temp. active and selective TiO2-doped Mn2O3 Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, consisting of 6 wt% TiO2, 6 wt% Mn2O3, 10 wt% Na2WO4 and SiO2 in balance, is developed by soln. combustion synthesis (SCS) method. This catalyst is capable of converting 20% CH4 with 70% selectivity to C2-C3 hydrocarbons even at 700 °C (catalyst bed temp.) and is stable for at least 250 h without deactivation sign, for a feed gas of 50% CH4 in air using a gas hourly space velocity of 8000 mL g-1cat. h-1. In contrast, the non-TiO2-doped SCS catalyst is almost inactive at 700 °C whereas it can achieve reactivity (∼24% CH4 conversion and ∼74% C2-C3 selectivity) comparable to the TiO2-doped one at 800 °C. XRD and Raman results evidently reveal that the formation of MnTiO3 during the OCM process appears to be important for the low-temp. OCM activity improvement by TiO2-doping.

A series of solid acid WO3/TiO2-supported lithium-manganese oxide (Li-Mn/WO3/TiO2) catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) were prepd. by the impregnation method. The XRD and XPS analyses showed that increasing the calcination temp. could promote the generation of Mn2+ and Mn3+ species and the anatase-to-rutile phase transformation of TiO2, which are beneficial to the OCM reaction. It was revealed by CO2-TPD, O2-TPD, H2-TPR, XPS, and CH4-TPSR that Li-Mn/WO3/TiO2 with higher calcination temp. possessed much stronger surface basicity, lower lattice oxygen mobility, and more abundant lattice oxygen, which are favorable for the selectivity to C2 hydrocarbons. The catalytic, structural, and spectroscopic results showed that the catalytic performance, structure, and properties of catalysts were little influenced by the calcination temp. of the WO3/TiO2 support. The optimized calcination temp. of the support and the catalyst is 800 °C, on which the highest C2 yield of 16.3 % was achieved at a reaction temp. of 750 °C.

Oxidative coupling of methane using catalysts synthesized by solution combustion method: Catalyst optimization and kinetic studies
Ghose, Ranjita; Hwang, Hyun Tae; Varma, Arvind

The Na2WO4-Mn/SiO2 catalyst has shown promise for oxidative coupling of methane (OCM). Our prior work demonstrates that 10%Na2WO4-5%Mn/SiO2 prepd. by soln. combustion synthesis (SCS) exhibits good performance in terms of C2 yield and ethylene to ethane ratio. In this work, we use SCS for prepn. of several modified Na2WO4-Mn/SiO2 catalysts for OCM. The catalyst compn. was optimized by addn. of different metals and Si precursor used. The optimized catalyst (5%La-10%Na2WO4-5%Mn/SiO2, using tetraethoxysilane as the Si precursor) showed the best performance for OCM, with C2 yield 27% and ethylene/ethane ratio 3.6 under optimized operating conditions, both values are among the highest reported in the literature. Kinetic studies for this catalyst indicated that methane conversion was first-order in methane and half-order in oxygen, implying that methane activation is likely to be rate-limiting and oxygen adsorption is dissociative. The formation rates of primary products (C2H6, CO and CO2) could be well described by the reaction scheme proposed in a prior work.

In search of membrane-catalyst materials for oxidative coupling of methane: Performance and phase stability studies of gadolinium-doped barium cerate and the impact of Zr doping
Igenegbai, Valentina Omoze; Meyer, Randall J.; Linic, Suljo

Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) is a promising technol. for the direct conversion of methane to ethylene and ethane (C2). This process is yet to be commercialized due its poor yield reflected in the formation of undesired products such as CO and CO2 (COx) as methane conversion increases, particularly in conventional packed bed reactors (PBRs). It has been argued that by applying O2- conducting membrane reactors that distribute the oxygen feed, the selectivity to the C2 products can be increased. A practical design for these membrane reactors would include combining a selective catalyst, preferably O2- conducting, with an O2- conducting membrane. In this work, we studied an O2- conducting material, gadolinium-doped barium cerate (BaCe0.8Gd0.2O3-δ or BCG), to evaluate its potential applicability as a catalyst and membrane in OCM membrane reactors. Furthermore, at low oxygen partial pressures, a C2+ selectivity of ∼90% was obtained at methane conversions of ∼3%. Although the C2+ yield from this material was stable over 48 h on stream at high methane conversions, X-ray diffraction data showed that the BCG perovskite phase, which is required for its conductive (membrane) properties, decomps. into BaCO3, CeO2 and Gd2O3 like phases, due to reactions with CO2. We showed that doping BCG with Zr was effective at suppressing the phase instability in OCM without significantly affecting the C2+ yields.

The promoting effect of ceria was studied on the oxidative coupling of methane reaction with Li/Ce/MgO and Na/Ce/MgO. Catalytic tests were conducted with un-promoted Li/MgO and Na/MgO catalysts and showed that samples doped with ceria affected the OCM reaction. In situ XRD results showed growth of MgO and CeO2 crystallites on the Na/Ce/MgO, decreasing the activity and selectivity. The Li/Ce/MgO catalyst presented small and stable crystallites which increased markedly the activity, selectivity and stability. Diffusion reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) results of calcined samples revealed the charge transfer from cerium to oxygen ions, as well as oxygen transfer into the lattice. Different sites may influence the selectivity in C2 and C2 yield. The Li/Ce/MgO catalyst presented higher methane conversion and C2 selectivity than the Na/Ce/MgO catalyst, probably due to different types of involved active site promoted by ceria during the reaction.

Noble metal doped M-MnxOy-Na2WO4/SiO2 (M = Pt, Ir, Rh) catalysts were prepd. via a wet impregnation method using mesoporous silica MCF-17 as support, and their performance in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) was studied in a fixed-bed flow reactor. The reaction was carried out at 750° under atm. pressure with a gas feed compn. of CH4:O2 = 4:1. The incorporation of the noble metals yielded an enhanced selectivity towards both C2 and C3 hydrocarbons as compared to the undoped MnxOy-Na2WO4/MCF-17 catalyst in the order of Rh-doped > Ir-doped > Pt-doped samples together with a lower olefin to paraffin ratio. The Ir-doped catalyst showed the highest overall yield for C2 prodn. Elemental anal., N2-adsorption, and x-ray powder diffraction (x-ray diffraction) measurements confirmed similar metal loading, surface area, and phase compn. for both the undoped and doped catalysts. Electron microscopy anal. showed a near-homogeneous distribution of Na and W but a higher tendency to form aggregates for Mn, with the Rh-doped catalyst being the best in overall elemental dispersion. XPS and temp.-programmed redn. (H2-TPR) results indicate a more reduced nature of the surface oxide species in the noble metal doped catalysts as compared to the undoped one. They also suggest a more optimized strength of interaction between the carbon intermediates and the surface of the noble metal doped catalysts, which in combination with the improved reducibility of Mn and W species and metal dispersion, accounted for the enhanced C2 prodn. on the noble metal doped MnxOy-Na2WO4/MCF-17 catalysts.

Ji, Shengfu; Xiao, Tiancun; Li, Shuben; Chou, Lingjun; Zhang, Bing; Xu, Chuanzhi; Hou, Ruiling; York, Andrew P. E.; Green, Malcolm L. H.

A series of M-W-Mn/SiO2 catalysts (M = Li, Na, K, Ba, Ca, Fe, Co, Ni, and Al) have been prepd. and their catalytic performance for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) was evaluated in a continuous-flow microreactor. The structural properties of the catalysts have been studied using XPS, laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR). In the trimetallic catalysts studied, there was evidence for WO4 tetrahedron on the surface in the Li-, Na-, and K-W-Mn/SiO2 catalysts, which is mainly present in the subsurface of the Ba-W-Mn/SiO2 catalyst. It appears that the WO4 has a strong interaction with the α-cristobalite support and is stabilized in the Na- and K-W-Mn/SiO2 catalysts. However, the WO4 species appear to be less stable in Li- or Ba-W-Mn/SiO2 catalysts, in which the support turns into quartz SiO2 or amorphous SiO2. The WO4 tetrahedron on the catalyst surface appears to play an essential role in achieving high CH4 conversion and high C2 hydrocarbon selectivity in the OCM reaction. Calcns. suggest that the WO4 tetrahedron interacts with the CH4, giving suitable geometry and energy matching with CH4, and this may account for the high OCM activities.

Na2WO4-TiO2-MnOx/SiO2 (SM) catalysts with alkali (Li, K, Rb, Cs) or alkali earth (Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba) oxide additives, which were prepd. using incipient wetness impregnation, were investigated for oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) to value-added hydrocarbons (C2+). A screening test that was performed on the catalysts revealed that SM with Sr (SM-Sr) had the highest yield of C2+. XPS analyses indicated that the catalysts with a relatively low binding energy of W 4f7/2 facilitated a high CH4 conversion. A combination of cryst. MnTiO3, Mn2O3, α-cristobalite, Na2WO4, and TiO2 phases was identified as an essential component for a remarkable improvement in the activity of the catalysts in the OCM reaction. In attempts to optimize the C2+ yield, 0.25 wt % Sr onto SM-Sr achieved the highest C2+ yield at 22.9% with a 62.5% C2+ selectivity and a 36.6% CH4 conversion. A stability test of the optimal catalyst showed that after 24 h of testing, its activity decreased by 18.7%.

This work assessed the effect of pH control on the oxidn. state and O storage capacity of catalysts, and their correlation with low temp. selective catalytic redn. (SCR) using Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts. Catalyst activity increased increases during low temp. (120-180°) SCR reaction when the active metal slurry and TiO2 pH was controlled at low levels during Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst prepn.. NH3 temp.-programmed desorption, diffuse reflectance IR Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), XPS, and O2-chemisorption characterized the catalyst. DRIFTS showed that NH3 adsorption on acid sites of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts, which exhibited excellent reaction activity for SCR reaction, increased vs. those over Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts. In particular, NH4+ sorbed on Bronsted acid sites greatly increased. When adsorbed NH3 reacted with injected NO + O2, adsorbed NH3 species rapidly decreased on Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts whose pH was controlled at low levels; the reaction rate greatly increased. XPS anal. showed the catalyst O storage capacity increase was due to decreased lattice O on the catalyst surface; adsorbed O species increased as non-stoichiometric Ce3+ species increased. Also, O2 chemisorption showed that O mobility increased for catalysts whose pH was controlled at low levels. Results indicated O mobility increased due to increased adsorbed O species, demonstrated by XPS. Thus, controlling pH during prepn. of Mn catalysts increased surface Bronsted acid sites and increased O mobility, due to increased in adsorbed O species, resulting in increased SCR activity.

A novel two-stage catalyst bed reactor was constructed comprising of the 5%Na2WO4-2%Mn/SiO2 particle catalyst and the 5%Na3PO4-2%Mn/SiO2/cordierite monolithic catalyst. The reaction performance of the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) in the two-stage bed reactor system was evaluated. The effects of the bed height and operation mode, as well as the reaction parameters such as reaction temp., CH4/O2 ratio and flowrate of feed gas on the catalytic performance were investigated. The results indicated that the two-stage bed reactor system exhibited a good performance for the OCM reaction when the feed gases were firstly passed through the particle catalyst bed and then to the monolithic catalyst bed. The CH4 conversion of 32.6% and C2 selectivity of 67.5% could be obtained with a particle catalyst bed height of 10 mm and a monolithic catalyst bed height of 50 mm in the two-stage bed reactor. Both of the CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity have been increased by 4.8% and 2.5%, resp., as compared with the 5%Na2WO4-2%Mn/SiO2 particle catalyst in a single-bed reactor and by 7.7% and 16.1%, resp., as compared with the 5%Na3PO4-2%Mn/SiO2/cordierite monolithic catalyst in a single-bed reactor. The catalytic performance of the OCM in the two-stage bed reactor system has been remarkably improved. The TPR results indicate the high temp. redn. oxygen species in the monolithic catalyst might be favorable to the formation of C2 products.

Kiani, Daniyal; Sourav, Sagar; Baltrusaitis, Jonas; Wachs, Israel E.

The literature for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) on supported Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts is systematically and critically reviewed. The influence of the precursors, starting SiO2 support crystallinity, synthesis method, calcination temp., and OCM reaction conditions on the catalyst structure is examd. The supported Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst system is found to be dynamic with the catalyst structure quite dependent on the set of variables. Although almost all of the reported studies have detd. the catalyst cryst. structures under ambient conditions (room temp. and air exposed), recent in situ/operando characterization study under OCM reaction conditions revealed that all previously detected cryst. phases of the active Mn-Na-W-O components are not present because the reaction temp. is above the m.ps. of their oxides. The presence of Na also induces the crystn. of the silica support to SiO2 (cristobalite) at elevated temps. The nature of the surface active sites under OCM reaction conditions is still not known because of the absence of in situ/operando surface spectroscopy characterization studies under relevant reaction conditions. Consequently, the proposed structure-activity models in the literature are highly speculative since they are lacking supporting data. The rate-detg.-step involves activation of the methane C-H bond by at. surface O* as demonstrated by a kinetic isotope effect (KIE) between CH4 and CD4. Although the reaction kinetics follow a Langmuir-Hinshelwood type mechanism, r = [CH4]1[O2]1/2, isotopic 18O2-16O2 studies have shown that the catalyst lattice also provides O* for the OCM reaction suggesting involvement of a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. Recommendations are given regarding the exptl. investigations that could establish the fundamental reaction aspects of OCM by supported Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts that would allow for the rational design of improved catalysts.

ethylene [74-85-1] And ethane [74-84-0] were synthesized by catalytic oxidative coupling of CH4 [74-82-8] at 1 atm and 500-1000°. A great no. of metal oxides, supported on an α-alumina support, were screened for activity and selectivity in the normal, concurrent feeding mode of reactants, as well as, in the sequential or feed programming mode. The concurrent feeding expts. gave low selectivities of 0-20 %, while feed programming expts. gave selectivities of ∼50%. In the latter case, however, a stainless-steel reactor became catalytically active for burning of methane to carbon oxides. Although a stainless-steel reactor was used in most of the work reported here, a quartz reactor was inert. The most active catalysts for C2 formation were the oxides of Sn, Pb, Sb, Bi, Tl, Cd, and Mn, while Li, Mg, Zn, Ti, Zr, Mo, Fe, Cr, W, Cu, Ag, Pt, Ce, V, B, and Al showed little or no activity. The low C2-forming activity of Pt and Ce, however, may be due to the secondary burning of C2's on the stainless-steel reactor walls. This also makes it difficult to quantify the C2-forming selectivity of the active metal oxides. The active metals seem to exhibit a common characteristic: they can cycle between at least two oxidn. states. Although there are differences in selectivities in C2 formation and carbon oxides formation, no correlation seems to exist with the free-energy changes in the oxidn. states. A possible mechanism for C2 formation from methane is proposed.

A review with 45 refs. The very large reserves of methane, which often are found in remote regions, could serve as a feedstock for the prodn. of chems. and as a source of energy well into the 21st century. Although methane currently is being used in such important applications as the heating of homes and the generation of hydrogen for ammonia synthesis, its potential for the prodn. of ethylene or liq. hydrocarbon fuels has not been fully realized. A no. of strategies are being explored at levels that range from fundamental science to engineering technol. These include: (a) stream and carbon dioxide reforming or partial oxidn. of methane to form carbon monoxide and hydrogen, followed by Fischer-Tropsch chem., (b) the direct oxidn. of methane to methanol and formaldehyde, (c) oxidative coupling of methane to ethylene, and (d) direct conversion to aroms. and hydrogen in the absence of oxygen. Each alternative has its own set of limitations; however, economical sepn. is common to all with the most important issues being the sepn. of oxygen from air and the sepn. of hydrogen or hydrocarbons from dil. product streams. Extensive utilization of methane for the prodn. of fuels and chems. appears to be near, but current economic uncertainties limit the amt. of research activity and the implementation of emerging technologies.

The mechanism of the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), a reaction discovered in the early 1980s, and the development of approaches to kinetic description of this reaction are analyzed. In addn. to being of potential practical significance as a single-step synthetic route from methane to ethylene, a valuable chem. and petrochem. semiproduct, OCM was the first heterogeneous-homogeneous process of this hitherto unknown type. Its distinctive feature is that it is impossible to sep. det. the methane conversion via the main pathway (into C2 hydrocarbons) in the homogeneous phase and on the catalyst surface, because reactive intermediates (Me radicals) result from the interaction of methane mols. with active sites of the surface, while the primary OCM product (ethane) results from the recombination of these radicals in the gas phase. The correlation between the phenomenol. regularities of the OCM process and its mechanism, the correlation between the nature of the active sites and the mechanism of activation of methane and oxygen, and the possibility of constructing a self-consistent kinetic model taking into account the specific features of the process-redox nature of the active sites and the free-radical character of the major intermediate compds.-are analyzed in detail.

A gas-phase reaction network involving reactive intermediates such as alkyl and alkyl peroxide radicals and alkyl hydroperoxides have long remained a mystery in oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) and oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODHE) reactions. Herein we report direct observations of gas-phase reactive intermediates including CH2, CH3•, C2H5•, CH3OO•, C2H5OO•, CH3OOH, and C2H5OOH during OCM and ODHE reactions over Li/MgO catalysts with an online synchrotron VUV photoionization mass spectrometer connected to a catalytic reactor with adjustable distances between the catalyst bed and the sampling nozzle of the mass spectrometer. Secondary reactions of these reactive intermediates in the gas phase are elucidated, and the reaction network of OCM and ODHE reactions is established. These results greatly deepen the mechanistic understanding of OCM and ODHE reactions necessary for developing efficient catalysts and designing proper reactors.

Four seemingly simple transformations related to the chemistry of methane will be addressed from mechanistic and conceptual points of view: 1) metal-mediated dehydrogenation to form metal carbene complexes, 2) the hydrogen-atom abstraction step in the oxidative dimerization of methane, 3) the mechanisms of the CH(4)→CH(3)OH conversion, and 4) the initial bond scission (C-H vs. O-H) as well as the rate-limiting step in the selective CH(3)OH→CH(2)O oxidation. State-of-the-art gas-phase experiments, in conjunction with electronic-structure calculations, permit identification of the elementary reactions at a molecular level and thus allow us to unravel detailed mechanistic aspects. Where appropriate, these results are compared with findings from related studies in solution or on surfaces.

A reaction-transport model that combines gas-phase reactions occurring within interstitial and intrapellet voids with surface reactions occurring on catalytic sites was used to describe the oxidative coupling of methane in packed-bed reactors, a typical example of bimodal (homogeneous-heterogeneous) reaction systems. A kinetic model for gas-phase reactions was assembled from available literature data; it describes well exptl. results in empty reactors. Simulations suggest that C2 yields greater than 8-9% are unattainable with CH4/O2 mixts. in homogeneous reactors. Staging the introduction of the oxygen reactant along the reactor length minimizes secondary oxidn. reactions by lowering the local O2 pressures, and leads to a slight increase in max. yield (12% for 200 injection points) but also to much larger required reactor vols. The introduction of an ideal catalytic function (Me and Et radical formation without full oxidn.) also increases max. C2 yields by increasing the concn. of Me radicals involved in bimol. coupling steps. However, C2 yields greater than 30% require selective catalysts with very high turnover rates (>100 s-1); higher rates become ultimately limited by intrapellet diffusion rates. Again, staging oxygen by multiple injection schemes increases attainable yields but requires larger reactor vols. and catalytic sites with low reaction order («1) in oxygen. For optimum conditions, staged oxygen injection techniques lead to C2 yields as high as 50%.

The chem. looping concept (CLC) has been implemented to suppress the formation of COx in an oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) reactor under a wide range of conditions. In comparison to the normal co-feeding strategy, this technique resulted in an enhanced C2 selectivity at the same methane conversions. Nevertheless, the obtained yield never exceeded 25% which is still lower than the min. value needed for industrializing OCM. The CLC was applied in mechanistic studies to investigate the consecutive reaction of the main products of OCM, i.e. ethane and ethene. The performance of the reaction of C2 components at 750 °C in the chem. looping reactor was compared with that obtained in the co-feeding expts. The effect of the surface adsorbed oxygen species on the reaction of both ethane and ethene was investigated. The results of these expts. reveal that some of the mechanistic assumptions about the OCM reaction are not compatible with the nature of MnxOy-Na2WO4/SiO2, one of the most stable and best performing catalysts known for this reaction. The yield limitation is shown to be inherent to the catalyst. However, this limitation should be solvable through the modified process concept aiming at the prodn. of ethane in a sepd. first step.

A review. Over the past few decades, natural gas prodn. has increased due to shale gas and tight oil prodn. This increase in availability and prodn. has prompted research into unconventional ways to use methane, the main component in natural gas. Methane can be directly converted to more valuable C2 products using oxidative coupling (OCM). This process has been studied extensively over the last several decades, however, it has not been commercialized due to low yields of the C2 products. The oxidative coupling of CH4 over Mn/Na2WO4/SIO2, Mn/Na2WO4/MgO, and NaMnO4/MgO catalysts was studied using both a co-feed flow system and a pulse reactor. Using a CH4/O2 ratio of ca. 8/1, at 800° and 1 atm, the CH4 conversion of 20% was achieved with C2+ selectivity of ≥80%, with no diluent in the reagents. The similar catalytic behaviors of the 3 catalysts suggest that a common active site, consisting of an Na-O-Mn species, may be involved. Results from a pulse reaction sequence (an O2 pulse followed by a series of pure CH4 pulses) indicate that the active species are not stable under reaction conditions unless gas phase O2 is present, and that bulk lattice oxygen does not participate in the CH4 coupling reaction when carried out in the co-feed mode. There is a linear relationship between the specific activity for CH4 conversion and the concn. of surface Mn, which is believed to be responsible for the activation of O2. The resulting form of oxygen then abstrs. a hydrogen atom from CH4. Sodium is essential for preventing the complete oxidn. of CH4, perhaps by isolating the Mn ions. The tungstate ions appear to impart stability to the catalysts.

Increased yields of higher hydrocarbons from CH4 [74-82-8] over MgO-SiO2 are obtained upon the addn. of alkali metals and alk. earths to the catalyst. Running redox cycles of alternating CH4 and air, a 15% Mn-5% Na pyrophosphate-SiO2 catalyst repeatedly gives a 17% yield of C2H6 [74-84-0], C2H4 [74-85-1], and higher hydrocarbons (77% selectivity and 22% conversion) for 2 min at 850° and gas space velocity 860 h-1. This represents an improvement of 40% selectivity over the alkali-free catalyst. The improvement arises largely by suppression of product oxidn. Further evidence is described for a mechanism involving surface-initiated gas phase Me radicals.

Characterization of Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 and Mn-Na2WO4/MgO catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane
Elkins, Trenton W.; Hagelin-Weaver, Helena E.
Applied Catalysis, A: General
(
2015
),

(

ACAGE4
; ISSN:
0926-860X
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
In this study, one of the most active catalysts in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2, was investigated in detail using x-ray diffraction (x-ray diffraction) and XPS to obtain more information about this complex catalyst. A poorly active Mn-Na2WO4/MgO and two ref. catalysts, Mn/SiO2 and Na2WO4/SiO2, were also included. X-ray diffraction reveals the presence of Na2WO4, Mn2O3 and the α-cristobalite phase of SiO2 on the active Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, which all have been identified as very important in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM). In addn. to facilitating the transformation from amorphous to cryst. α-cristobalite SiO2, the presence of Na2WO4 also yields a higher surface concn. of manganese. While this is necessary, it is not sufficient, for a highly active catalyst, as the poorly active Mn-Na2WO4/MgO also has a high manganese surface concn. However, in contrast to the very stable Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, the MgO support is not able to stabilize the specific Na2WO4 and Mn2O3 phases and a no. of NaxWOy compds. with varying Na:W ratios together with MnO2 and mixed manganese compds. are identified by x-ray diffraction. The broad Na 1s and W 4f XPS peaks support the presence of more than one NaxWOy compd. on the surface of the Mn-Na2WO4/MgO catalyst. The fact that Na2WO4 and Mn2O3 are not stable on the MgO-supported catalyst is likely one reason for its poor activity, as the active site is believed to involve a distorted WO4 tetrahedron stabilized by Na (and α-cristobalite SiO2), and accessible Mn3+ in close proximity to the Na2WO4 may be necessary to yield a highly active catalyst. The Na:W surface concn. ratio of the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst is significantly higher (5.8) than the stoichiometric Na:W ratio of Na2WO4 (2.0) revealing a surface enriched in sodium. This is due to some of the sodium interacting closely with the SiO2 as evidenced by shifts in the Na 1s and Si 2p peaks to lower binding energies than expected for SiO2 and Na2WO4. The Na may be important in the activation of oxygen species on the surface toward hydrogen abstraction. The importance of the specific Na2WO4 oxide is further supported by the H4Na2WO6 phase which is obsd. on the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst after reaction. This phase has not been identified previously on the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, but corroborates earlier conclusions that Na2WO4 is important and suggests that Na2WO4 is indeed involved in the hydrogen abstraction from methane, the important first step in the oxidative coupling of methane. The strong interactions obsd. between all the species (Mn, Na, W and Si) on this catalyst may also indicate that the interface between Na2WO4 and Mn2O3 is important in this reaction.

Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) is a promising method for the direct conversion of methane to ethene and ethane (C2 products). Among the catalysts reported previously, Mn2O3-Na2WO4/SiO2 showed the highest conversion and selectivity, but only at 800° to 900°C, which represents a substantial challenge for commercialization. We report a TiO2-doped Mn2O3-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst by using Ti-MWW zeolite as TiO2 dopant as well as SiO2 support, enabling OCM with 26% conversion and 76% C2-C3 selectivity at 720°C because of MnTiO3 formation. MnTiO3 triggers the low-temp. Mn2+↔Mn3+ cycle for O2 activation while working synergistically with Na2WO4 to selectively convert methane to C2-C3. We also prepd. a practical Mn2O3-TiO2-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst in a ball mill. This catalyst can be transformed in situ into MnTiO3-Na2WO4/SiO2, yielding 22% conversion and 62% selectivity at 650°C. Our results will stimulate attempts to understand more fully the chem. of MnTiO3-governed low-temp. activity, which might lead to com. exploitation of a low-temp. OCM process.

The Mn2O3-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst is the most promising one among the enormous catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) but only at above 800 °C. No doubt that lowering temp. of the OCM process is at the forefront of this catalysis field. A promising low-temp. active and selective TiO2-doped Mn2O3 Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, consisting of 6 wt% TiO2, 6 wt% Mn2O3, 10 wt% Na2WO4 and SiO2 in balance, is developed by soln. combustion synthesis (SCS) method. This catalyst is capable of converting 20% CH4 with 70% selectivity to C2-C3 hydrocarbons even at 700 °C (catalyst bed temp.) and is stable for at least 250 h without deactivation sign, for a feed gas of 50% CH4 in air using a gas hourly space velocity of 8000 mL g-1cat. h-1. In contrast, the non-TiO2-doped SCS catalyst is almost inactive at 700 °C whereas it can achieve reactivity (∼24% CH4 conversion and ∼74% C2-C3 selectivity) comparable to the TiO2-doped one at 800 °C. XRD and Raman results evidently reveal that the formation of MnTiO3 during the OCM process appears to be important for the low-temp. OCM activity improvement by TiO2-doping.

The oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) was performed using Na2WO4/Mn catalysts supported on Mg/Ti/Si mixed oxides. Na2WO4/Mn/Mg0.05Ti0.05Si0.90On exhibited a 23.1% C2 yield at 800 °C, which is a 35% higher C2 yield than that obtained using conventional Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 in this study. The formation of Mg/Ti-doped α-cristobalite SiO2 was obsd. for supported Na2WO4/Mn catalysts, and their improved catalytic activity could be attributed to the suppressed incorporation of Na/W/Mn compds. into the α-cristobalite SiO2 structure and the existence of OCM-active Na/W/Mn compds. exposed on the support surface. X-ray diffraction, XPS, Raman spectroscopy, and O2-temp.-programmed desorption were performed in an effort to understand the improved catalytic OCM activity of Mg/Ti-doped SiO2-supported Na2WO4/Mn catalysts.

A series of solid acid WO3/TiO2-supported lithium-manganese oxide (Li-Mn/WO3/TiO2) catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) were prepd. by the impregnation method. The XRD and XPS analyses showed that increasing the calcination temp. could promote the generation of Mn2+ and Mn3+ species and the anatase-to-rutile phase transformation of TiO2, which are beneficial to the OCM reaction. It was revealed by CO2-TPD, O2-TPD, H2-TPR, XPS, and CH4-TPSR that Li-Mn/WO3/TiO2 with higher calcination temp. possessed much stronger surface basicity, lower lattice oxygen mobility, and more abundant lattice oxygen, which are favorable for the selectivity to C2 hydrocarbons. The catalytic, structural, and spectroscopic results showed that the catalytic performance, structure, and properties of catalysts were little influenced by the calcination temp. of the WO3/TiO2 support. The optimized calcination temp. of the support and the catalyst is 800 °C, on which the highest C2 yield of 16.3 % was achieved at a reaction temp. of 750 °C.

The Na2WO4-Mn/SiO2 catalyst has shown promise for oxidative coupling of methane (OCM). Our prior work demonstrates that 10%Na2WO4-5%Mn/SiO2 prepd. by soln. combustion synthesis (SCS) exhibits good performance in terms of C2 yield and ethylene to ethane ratio. In this work, we use SCS for prepn. of several modified Na2WO4-Mn/SiO2 catalysts for OCM. The catalyst compn. was optimized by addn. of different metals and Si precursor used. The optimized catalyst (5%La-10%Na2WO4-5%Mn/SiO2, using tetraethoxysilane as the Si precursor) showed the best performance for OCM, with C2 yield 27% and ethylene/ethane ratio 3.6 under optimized operating conditions, both values are among the highest reported in the literature. Kinetic studies for this catalyst indicated that methane conversion was first-order in methane and half-order in oxygen, implying that methane activation is likely to be rate-limiting and oxygen adsorption is dissociative. The formation rates of primary products (C2H6, CO and CO2) could be well described by the reaction scheme proposed in a prior work.

Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) is a promising technol. for the direct conversion of methane to ethylene and ethane (C2). This process is yet to be commercialized due its poor yield reflected in the formation of undesired products such as CO and CO2 (COx) as methane conversion increases, particularly in conventional packed bed reactors (PBRs). It has been argued that by applying O2- conducting membrane reactors that distribute the oxygen feed, the selectivity to the C2 products can be increased. A practical design for these membrane reactors would include combining a selective catalyst, preferably O2- conducting, with an O2- conducting membrane. In this work, we studied an O2- conducting material, gadolinium-doped barium cerate (BaCe0.8Gd0.2O3-δ or BCG), to evaluate its potential applicability as a catalyst and membrane in OCM membrane reactors. Furthermore, at low oxygen partial pressures, a C2+ selectivity of ∼90% was obtained at methane conversions of ∼3%. Although the C2+ yield from this material was stable over 48 h on stream at high methane conversions, X-ray diffraction data showed that the BCG perovskite phase, which is required for its conductive (membrane) properties, decomps. into BaCO3, CeO2 and Gd2O3 like phases, due to reactions with CO2. We showed that doping BCG with Zr was effective at suppressing the phase instability in OCM without significantly affecting the C2+ yields.

The promoting effect of ceria was studied on the oxidative coupling of methane reaction with Li/Ce/MgO and Na/Ce/MgO. Catalytic tests were conducted with un-promoted Li/MgO and Na/MgO catalysts and showed that samples doped with ceria affected the OCM reaction. In situ XRD results showed growth of MgO and CeO2 crystallites on the Na/Ce/MgO, decreasing the activity and selectivity. The Li/Ce/MgO catalyst presented small and stable crystallites which increased markedly the activity, selectivity and stability. Diffusion reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) results of calcined samples revealed the charge transfer from cerium to oxygen ions, as well as oxygen transfer into the lattice. Different sites may influence the selectivity in C2 and C2 yield. The Li/Ce/MgO catalyst presented higher methane conversion and C2 selectivity than the Na/Ce/MgO catalyst, probably due to different types of involved active site promoted by ceria during the reaction.

Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM): Effect of noble metal (M = Pt, Ir, Rh) doping on the performance of mesoporous silica MCF-17 supported MnxOy-Na2WO4 catalysts
Liu, Wen-Chi; Ralston, Walter T.; Melaet, Gerome; Somorjai, Gabor A.
Applied Catalysis, A: General
(
2017
),
545
(
),
17-23
CODEN:

.
(
Elsevier B.V.
